awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Linguistic Accommodation to Southern Speech
awd_abstract_narration:
Previous linguistic research has shown that speakers accommodate by imitating the same linguistic forms they observe an interlocutor using. It is not known whether speakers also accommodate by using linguistic forms they expect from an interlocutor based on social cues, even if the forms are absent from the input. The dissertation targets a Southern variant---monophthongal /ay/---where the vowel in 'ride' sounds more like 'rod.' The project examines whether speakers produce more monophthongal /ay/ when conversing with a Southern talker who never uses the /ay/ vowel, as well as the cognitive mechanisms responsible for this behavior. Understanding how sociolinguistic expectations are formed and accessed during expectation-driven accommodation contributes to a general understanding of how social stereotypes are formed, mentally represented, and utilized.

The project employs a novel word-naming game paradigm designed to elicit tokens of /ay/ from participants while exposing them to Southern speech that contains no /ay/ tokens. Acoustic properties of participants' /ay/ tokens are compared before and after exposure to a Southern or Midland (control) talker to determine whether accommodation occurs. Experiment 1 investigates whether accommodation based on expectations alone occurs. Experiment 2 tests whether expectation-driven accommodation is socially or structurally rooted by manipulating social cues (dialect labels) and structural cues (linguistic variants). Experiment 3 uses a joint perception-production task to determine whether participants exhibit /ay/-category boundary shifts, and whether such perceptual shifts predict accommodative behavior. This task attempts to pinpoint the perceptual changes that must take place for accommodation to occur, as well as understand the role of social information in both early perceptual changes and subsequent production behaviors. Self-reported surveys are paired with all three experiment to gauge the influence of social, cognitive, and attitudinal measures in accommodative behavior. Results contribute to scientific understanding of the relationship between perception and linguistic production, as well as the mental relationships between social and linguistic knowledge.

por.por_cntn:
During the funding period, speech production and perception data was collected from over 600 participants in one of the largest-scale projects on convergence—the phenomenon when language users temporarily shift their speech toward one another in interpersonal communication. Multiple experiments with slightly different goals produced the same basic finding: people shift their speech to produce the vowel in ‘ride’ more like someone from the U.S. south (so it sounds more like ‘rod’) when listening to a talker from the U.S. south, even if the southern talker never actually produced that vowel. No such shift occurred when participants listened to a midland talker (control). This is some of the first experimental evidence for what we refer to as ‘expectation-driven convergence,’ or imitation of expected rather than observed linguistic features. The fact that people exhibit this behavior is notable because it tells us that language users have knowledge about detailed linguistic forms and social factors and that they use this knowledge when they speak and process speech. It also tells us that imitation can target features that speakers are not presently observing, which has implications for the cognitive processes responsible for this behavior.

In addition to establishing expectation-driven convergence as a real and replicable behavior, this project tested a novel experimental paradigm, The Word Naming Task, for eliciting targeted naturalistic speech data while facilitating interaction and increasing ecological validity. Unlike existing experimental paradigms for eliciting convergence, the Word Naming Task uses a game-like presentation of “clues” to elicit specific words without ever hearing these words. Baseline speech elicited with visually presented clues is then compared to exposure speech elicited with auditorily-presented clues to determine whether convergence shifts have occurred. This method has been shown to be successful in eliciting expectation-driven convergence and may prove useful for future work on imitation. 

This projected has also provided two undergraduate students in linguistics first-hand experience in experimental design and data analysis, which they have utilized in their own academic work.

Finally, several key findings have come out of this work that have broader impacts. For one, results showed that participants also shifted in they way they perceived words with the vowel in ‘ride,’ such that they were more likely to say southern like productions (e.g., ‘brahb’ for ‘bribe’) were words after hearing a southerner who never produced any of these words. These perceptual shifts occurred for all speakers who exhibited production shifts, suggesting perceptual adjustments are a necessary but not sufficient prerequisite for convergence in production, and that other factors come into play in determining whether a perceptual shift will go on to influence speech production. Further, one version of the experiment found a notable difference in convergence behaviors between southern participants and non-southern participants: southerners exhibited convergence when they heard other southern-sounding vowels from the southern model talker, but non-southerners were more likely to converge when they were told the talker was “a southerner,” regardless of how the talker sounded. This indicates different routes through which information about southerners and southern speech is learned, mentally represented, and utilized across these two groups with varying degrees of sociolinguistic experience and has implications for our understanding of how social stereotypes are formed and updated.
